item.title: Xiao Gang, China’s Top Securities Regulator, Ousted Over Market Tumult
item.description: Xiao Gang was chief of the China Securities Regulatory Commission. His replacement is Liu Shiyu, chairman of the Agricultural Bank of China.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Xiao Gang, who was replaced as chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, had been criticized for allowing a speculative bubble to form in the country’s stock market.

item.title: Umberto Eco, 84, Best-Selling Academic Who Navigated Two Worlds, Dies
item.description: Mr. Eco was an expert in the arcane field of semiotics whose seven works of fiction included the blockbuster medieval mystery “The Name of the Rose.”
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN KANDELL
item.media:credit: Roberto Serra/Iguana Press, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Umberto Eco in Bologna, Italy, last year. As a semiotician, Mr. Eco studied signs and symbols.

item.title: Reporters’ Group Calls for Turkey to Release Syrian Citizen-Journalist
item.description: The Committee to Protect Journalists said the journalist, Rami Jarrah, had been detained for unclear reasons after reporting in Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: New Chinese Rules on Foreign Firms’ Online Content
item.description: New regulations will forbid any foreign company from publishing online content in China without the government’s consent.
item.category: State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television (China)
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA and PAUL MOZUR
item.media:description: A street scene in Beijing. Beginning March 10, foreign companies or foreign joint ventures operating in China will be restricted from disseminating a wide range of content online, including text, maps, games, animation, audio and video, without government approval.

item.title: U.S. Bombing in Libya Reveals Limits of Strategy Against ISIS
item.description: The strikes, which Western officials said targeted a senior operative linked to attacks in Tunisia, highlighted a growing gap in American military and diplomatic efforts.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH BEN HUBBARD and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The aftermath of airstrikes on Friday in Sabratha, Libya. A Tunisian militant linked to attacks on tourists last year was targeted.

item.title: Obscure Kurdish Group Claims Hand in Bombing Turks
item.description: The Kurdistan Freedom Hawks claimed responsibility for a bombing that killed 28 in Turkey’s capital, but Turkey’s leaders continued to blame a different Kurdish group, an ally of the United States.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Saudis Cut Off Funding for Military Aid to Lebanon
item.description: The move was a new step in a proxy war between countries who are on opposing sides in the wars in Yemen and Syria and competing for influence elsewhere across the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: E.U. Deal Clears Path for British Referendum on Membership
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron agreed to a package of concessions that clear the way for him to call for a vote in Britain on whether to cut ties to the union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain arriving Friday for the second day of a European Union summit meeting in Brussels.

item.title: After Tests in the North, Conservatives in South Korea Call for a Nuclear Program
item.description: After nuclear tests and satellite launches in North Korea, a small band of conservative politicians and pundits in South Korea are pushing a strategy of arming their own country.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Smoke bombs exploding near South Korean tanks in a live-fire exercise on Thursday in Yangpyeong.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Will Democracy Follow Capitalism Into Cuba?
item.description: President Obama will encounter a different, more enterprising country in his visit next month. But freedom remains a distant goal.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN RATTNER
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times

item.title: W.H.O. Advises Caution, but Not a Halt, in Blood Collection in Zika-Affected Areas
item.description: With the virus rapidly spreading throughout Latin America and the Caribbean, it may be “logistically impossible” to import blood for all of the region, officials say.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

item.title: News Analysis: Francis and Trump: Populist Leaders Preaching Divergent Messages
item.description: Pope Francis and Donald J. Trump each has diagnosed similar societal issues, seeking followers in seas churning with anger, dislocation, spiritual alienation and economic inequality.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Proof of Zika’s Role in Birth Defects Still Months Away, W.H.O. Says
item.description: While the evidence is strong that the virus is behind Brazil’s surge of birth defects, experts are waiting for pregnant women in a clinical trial to start giving birth in June.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Dr. Bruce Aylward, the W.H.O’’s head of emergency response, in a news conference on Friday.

item.title: Cameroon Blames Boko Haram in Pair of Suicide Bombings
item.description: A week after Cameroon began a new offensive against the militant group, two attackers detonated explosives in Mémé, local reports said, killing nearly two dozen people.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: FRANCOIS ESSOMBA and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Brother of Mohammed Merah, Killer in 2012 Attacks in France, May Face Trial
item.description: The Paris prosecutor said Abdelkader Merah had helped plan the killings of three soldiers and four civilians, including three children, in southwestern France.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Price of Gas Skyrockets in Venezuela (to 38 Cents a Gallon)
item.description: While the price, about 10 cents per liter, is still far below world rates, for drivers here it is an essential shift from paying basically nothing.
item.dc:creator: MARÍA EUGENIA DÍAZ and NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man filled his truck in Morón, Venezuela, last month, when gasoline cost a fraction of a cent per liter.

item.title: Kizza Besigye, Main Opposition Candidate in Uganda, Is Arrested Again
item.description: Mr. Besigye was arrested for the second time in two days as voting continued amid unrest in the capital.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON

item.title: Arrest of Refugee Fuels U.S. Debate on Immigration Policy
item.description: Both sides point to the case of a California man suspected of going to Syria to fight with terrorist groups and of lying about it to the authorities.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON
item.media:description: Benjamin Galloway, the lawyer for Syrian refugee Aws Mohammed Younis al-Jayab, outside a court in Sacramento last month.

item.title: In Britain, a Green Utility Company Sees Winds of Change
item.description: Instead of doubling down on renewable power after the United Nations climate accord in Paris, the utility, SSE, is rethinking its energy mix.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Electricity pylons lead away from the gas-fired power station at Keadby and a windmill belonging to the adjacent wind farm.

item.title: Opinion: World War I’s Iconic, Ironic Battle
item.description: It’s the centennial of Verdun. But what exactly are we commemorating?
item.dc:creator: PAUL JANKOWSKI
item.media:description: French troops under shellfire during the Battle of Verdun.
